page.title: 03Trees and Stone_Charnwood
page.content: There are very few signs now of the former oakwoods but about a fifth of the area is covered by small woods and spinneys of mixed or coniferous trees mainly in the southern and eastern sections_some commercial,some in nature reserves,some in characteristic clumps on the rocky summits of hills. In the valleys,roads are lined with oak holly and rowan.Walls of local stone are a feature round the 5 to 10 acre fields.The buildings which are scattered singly over the fields are almost all of local materials.Since the Charnian stone is so hard and splintery building takes the form of random rubble with brick dressings round doors and windows with brick stacks for chimneys.Roofs are of local blue Swithland slate usually covered with lichens which with the patchy purple and green stone appears sombre.
